Hey Millington Family!

We have been working with Ritter to create a program for our MMSD kiddos and families. Please see attached application and flyer for discounted Ritter High Speed Wireless Internet. There are a few stipulations. See below.

Additionally, in the “Student’s School Seal” area of the application you will need to get your school to stamp the applications with their school’s stamp. Once the student/family completes the application they (the family) will submit it to Ritter. The instructions are on the application form.

The terms of service are on the flyer, but here is the TL:DR (too long didn’t read)

- Family won’t qualify if they have had Ritter Internet in the past 90 days
- Pricing only good for the school year
- There is NO install fee
- Service is ~$37 dollars a month
- Must be a current student of Millington Municipal Schools

Application and Flyer can be found here: https://www.millingtonschools.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=90525&pageId=49971229

School lunches. Plans for highways. Support for firefighters and families in need. Census results affect our community every day. The Census drives how communities are funded and plays a part in our Municipality's future!

Hello Millington Family!

We wanted to welcome our newest family member! It is with resounding elation that we welcome Mr. Kyle Wright into the Millington Family. Kyle comes to serve alongside us as the new CFO of Millington Municipal Schools! We are excited that Kyle has chosen Millington Municipal Schools as his new home and we look forward to the leadership and financial direction that Kyle has to bestow.

Previously, Kyle worked as the Financial and Human Resources Director of Lakeland, TN and as a Senior Managing Consultant at the Memphis office of PFM Financial Advisors.

Kyle graduated from Pennsylvania State University in 2008 with a degree in economics. Kyle is currently enrolled in the Master of Accounting program at the University of Memphis and finishes this semester. He plans to become a Certified Public Accountant upon completion of the Master’s program.

After much deliberation and thoughtful consideration, Millington Municipal Schools has chosen Mr. Mark Neal as the next Principal of Millington Central High School. Mr. Mark Neal will pick up the Trojan torch passed on by Dr. Donald Durley. This torch will illuminate the path of the MCHS Trojans to a new Elysium of prosperity. Mr. Mark Neal comes back to us from Melrose High School in which he was part of a team that helped the school grow to new heights. Mr. Neal is a native of Tipton County and a graduate of UT Martin. He began his professional career in August of 2000 at MCHS spending eight years as a teacher, three years as an assistant Principal and eventually moving to the position of Principal of MCHS. Mr. Neal has spent the last five years as Principal of Melrose High School.
Mr. Mark Neal accepted the job of Principal of MCHS Friday, June, 7th 2019 and will begin leadership July 1st. Millington Municipal Schools warmly welcomes him and looks forward to a great tenure and time of growth for Mr. Neal as he comes back home to MCHS.

Mrs. Joanna Blankenship has been volunteering with the Make-A-Wish foundation since 2016. She volunteers in memory of her daughter Cassy Colunga. Make-A-Wish granted Cassy’s wish, an Alaskan cruise, in 2014 after she was diagnosed with a terminal brain tumor. Mrs. Blankenship personally knows what a powerful impact a wish can have on a child. It renews a child’s hope, while serving to strengthen and empower a child that is battling a critical illness.

Thank you to Millington Central High School and E.A. Harrold Elementary for raising donations for the Make-A-Wish World Wish Day. MCHS raised $327.23 and E. A. Harrold Elementary raised $300.00. These donations will help Make-A-Wish continue to grant wishes to children diagnosed with a critical illness. Wishes are made possible through the hard work of many dedicated staff, volunteers, donors and supporters.

MCHS juniors will take the ACT test tomorrow, April 2. Here are some tips to help them do the best they can!

1. DON’T CRAM!
You can certainly review but do not cram new information into your brain.

2. PACK YOUR BAG!
Have everything ready the night before so you can spend the next morning eating a healthy breakfast. Bring with you two No. 2 pencils, an eraser, a drink (water), and snacks.

4. SET YOUR ALARMS!
Make sure you arrive to school on time!

5. SLEEP AND EAT WELL!
Get at least eight hours of sleep. Also, a healthy dinner and breakfast will help you feel your best.

GO TROJANS!

post_text: Do you know what the hiring process is to become a Durham School Services bus driver? Besides the normal face to face interview that most jobs require, potential bus drivers must pass drug and alcohol testing. A company background check is completed by a third party as well as a finger print background check through the FBI. Candidates Motor Vehicle Records (MVR) are reviewed for a complete driving history including suspended licenses, traffic tickets, DUI, or DWI. Drivers must have a DOT physical completed, not only to get hired but also administered each year, where a medical examiner qualifies them physically able to fulfill their driving duties. Drivers must obtain a CDL driver’s license with a S endorsement to drive a school bus. This may sound like a lot but it ensures that we have capable, safety conscious drivers transporting our precious cargo.

This picture shows a small portion of what a driven path and all the stops made look like through Zonar. This is just one of many resources used to ensure safety and accountability for our district through our partnership with Durham School Services.

post_text: Do you know what a child check is? A child check is when a bus driver walks down the bus aisle to look on and under every seat for sleeping children and lost items. Child checks are completed after drivers drop off the last student on each run. This means each driver performs 6 child checks daily, 3 in the AM and 3 in the PM. One check is completed after the 1st tier high/middle school run, one after the 2nd tier elementary run, and one upon returning to the bus lot (twice daily for both AM & PM routes). There are child check probes strategically located on both sides of the bus and over the rear exit door where drivers must scan their Zonar wand to signal a digital indication that area was checked. Once drivers have completed their last child check for both AM & PM, each driver places this placard in the back window of the bus. This gives added assurance that each bus has been thoroughly checked and no children were left behind. Our drivers even have a safety motto they often share over the radio: "A child check is not complete until you've checked under every seat."

post_text: Do you know our Durham bus drivers are typically not allowed to make a right turn on a red light? It’s very easy to misjudge the speed of oncoming vehicles and school buses have such slow acceleration that making a right turn on red can be hazardous. Our drivers must radio in to their Operations Supervisor with their location and request permission to make a right turn on red. Only after permission is granted are they allowed to proceed with caution. So, next time you’re stuck behind a school bus at a red light where a right turn can be made, practice a little patience and remember the driver is only following safe driving policy.

post_text: Do you know the yellow & red flashing lights on a school bus are similar to traffic lights? A bus driver generally activates their yellow lights approximately 200 feet before a student’s bus stop. When the yellow lights are flashing other drivers should prepare to stop, much like a caution or yield sign. Unlike a yellow traffic light, drivers should not speed up to pass by! When a bus comes to a complete stop the driver will open the door and that’s when the stop sign swings out and the red lights start flashing. The red lights do NOT come on before the bus comes to a complete stop. This is why it’s so important to pay attention to the yellow flashing lights and prepare to stop. Remember, passing a school bus while the stop sign arm is extended or the red lights are flashing is against the law.

Welcome to our new post called “Do You Know”. Each week we will share a school bus safety tip or fact to help our community gain knowledge about our school bus transportation services.

Do you know when to stop for a school bus? The correct answer is whenever you see the red flashing lights. The only time you do not have to stop is when there is at least 5 feet of unpaved space or any raised median or physical barrier on a divided highway. A turning lane is not a physical barrier between lanes, therefore, drivers should stop in both directions. It’s darker in the mornings now so make sure to pay close attention and STOP when you see red flashing lights. It could save a child’s life.
